dc:description: The *CDH11* gene located on chromosome 16 at 16q21 encodes a type II classical cadherin from the cadherin superfamily, integral membrane proteins that mediate calcium-dependent cell-cell adhesion. The protein is composed of 5 extracellular cadherin domains, one transmembrane domain, and one intracellular domain. *CDH11* was first reported in relation to Elsahy-Waters syndrome (ESWS), also known as branchioskeletogenital syndrome, in 2016 (Anazi et al., 2016 PMID: 27431290). ESWS is characterized by significant craniofacial dysmorphism (including hypertelorism, broad forehead, thick eyebrows with synophrys, flat malar regions, broad/ bulbous noses, mild prognathism), multiple congenital ocular, dental, digital, genital and vertebral anomalies, moderate intellectual disability and/or moderate hearing loss.  Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found differences in molecular mechanisms, inheritance patterns, and phenotypic variability among individuals with biallelic versus monoallelic *CDH11* variants. Therefore, the following disease entities have been split into multiple disease entities, AR Elsahy-Waters syndrome (ESWS) (OMIM:211380), and AD Teebi hypertelorism syndrome 2 (TBHS2) (OMIM:619736). The split curation for AD TBHS2 has been curated separately. All variants reported to date in the recessive condition are putative loss of function variants, including nonsense, frameshifts, essential splice donor and/or acceptor variants impacting the extracellular domains. Five homozygous probands from consanguineous families in five publications have been included in this curation (PMID:27431290; Taskiran et al., 2017 PMID: 28988429; Harms et al., 2018 PMID: 29271567; Castori et al., 2018 PMID: 30194892; Minatogawa et al., 2021 PMID: 34278706). The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be loss of function. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by functional alteration of patient cells (PMID: 28988429) and several homozygous null animal models recapitulating cranial, femoral, and snout dysmorphology (Kawaguchi et al., 2001 PMID: 11450702), hearing loss (Kiyama et al., 2018 PMID: 29967341), and genitourinary malformations (IMPC database, Dickinson et al., 2016 PMID: 27626380). In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between *CDH11* and AR ESWS. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Syndromic Disorders GCEP on the meeting date May 17th, 2024 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description: hematoxylin-eosin staining of paraffin embedded sections of the middle ear of adult wt mice compared to cdh11-/- mice
evidence.rdfs:label: Kiyama 2018 Cdh11 middle ear expression

evidence.dc:description: We do not typically score functional evidence for null alleles
CDH11 expression is reduced in homozygous p.Ile372MetfsTer9 fibroblasts of proband compared to het parent and healthy wt control.
evidence.rdfs:label: Taskiran Fibroblast expression

evidence.dc:description: Immunostaining of CDH11 shows lack of CDH11 protein in patient fibroblasts with c.1116_1117delinsGATCATCAG, p.Ile372MetfsTer9 compared to healthy control fibroblasts without the variant. Fibroblast doubling time was also lengthened in proband fibroblasts compared to healthy controls.
evidence.rdfs:label: Taskiran fibroblasts

evidence.dc:description: Similarly, knocking down CDH11 abolished collagen and elastin synthesis in human cells, and consequently reduced their ability to generate force.
evidence.rdfs:label: Row 2016 Cdh11-/- mouse

evidence.dc:description: Both model organism and subset of ESWS patients presented with hearing loss
evidence.rdfs:label: Kiyama Cdh11-/- mouse

evidence.dc:description: SD GCEP Scoring Guidance Specifications for consanguinity and homozygosity

evidence.rdfs:label: Taskiran II–1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Dx: Two sisters from a consanguineous couple had facial dysmorphic features and glaucoma.  Hypertelorism noted at birth, other features examined age 4
Craniofacial dysmorphism: broad foreheads, hypertelorism, thick eyebrows with synophrys, flat malar regions, broad/ bulbous noses, mild prognathism. 
Eye: Glaucoma, megalocorneas; younger also had cataracts + phthisis bulbi., 
Digital: Bilateral partial cutaneous syndactyly of 2nd & 3rd fingers
Dental:  Hx of impacted teeth with dentigerous cyst in the elder one
Developmental: Intellectual disability (mild and borderline).
Skeletal: Short stature (3rd %ile for height for age 4)

evidence.dc:description: Deducting half a point for consanguinity. Not deducting half a point for homozygosity because there is functional data in Figure 5c,5d, 5f (truncated protein was undetectable in fibroblasts of one of the proband II–1).
Deducting half a point from each for homozygosity and consanguinity per SD GCEP Scoring Guidance Specifications

evidence.rdfs:label: Castori 2018
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Both sibs had mixed hearing loss. 
Craniofacial dysmorphism: brachycephaly, facial asymmetry, right head tilting, high forehead, broad nose w/ bulbous tip, prominent mandible secondary to an underdeveloped midface & extensive premature tooth loss (Figure 1B). 
Skeletal: vertebral body fusion of C2-C3 & posterior arch fusion of L2-L3, which were lacking in 51-year-old sister who displayed microcephaly. 
Dental:  radicular dentin dysplasia (Figure 1C) associated with recurrent dentigerous cysts
Genital:  hypospadias in the male. 
Skin: thick and remarkably furrowed (pachydermia), especially over the forehead and the glabella (Figure 1B). 
Hair: Progressive alopecia was evident over the scalp in both.

evidence.rdfs:label: Harms 2018 Family 2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Developmental: Global DD, delayed walker (2y), speech not understandable. Normal growth
Craniofacial dysmorphism: broad forehead w/ prominent veins, severe hypertelorism w/ proptosis, divergent strabismus, downslanting palpebral fissures, small cleft of upper lid in the junction between medial 1/3, & lateral 2/3, very thick eyebrows esp in the middle part, very broad nasal bridge, high arched, & narrow palate, low set, posteriorly rotated ears
Dental: extensive caries, & midface retraction with overbite (Fig 1b). 
Eye: Oph evaluation revealed restricted eye movements due to extreme proptosis, inability to close the eyelids w/ resulting exposure keratitis, & megalocornea w/ large optic cups (Fig 1b). Brain MRI was normal. 
Skeletal: delayed bone age & coning of the middle phalanx of the fifth finger bilaterally

evidence.rdfs:label: Minatogawa 2021 Proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
53yo male.
Fam hx: Parents consang. 1st cousins, unavailable for genotyping. Healthy sister. 
Craniofacial dysmorphism: brachycephaly, asymmetrical face, midface hypoplasia, a broad forehead, frontal bossing, vertical forehead creases, thick eyebrows, synophrys, proptosis, hypertelorism, down slanting palpebral fissures, infraorbital fold, a broad and flat nasal bridge, a bulbous nasal tip, thin upper lip, a high arched palate, dental malocclusion, low-set ears, and prognathism 
Digital: cutaneous syndactyly in 2–3 digits of the right hand, amputated left third distal phalanx because of an accident, and deformities of the fingers (Figure 1(c)). He also showed hallux valgus and bilateral cutaneous syndactyly in 2–3 toes
Spinal: atlantoaxial instability due to posterior displacement of dens, thoracic fusion, thoracic butterfly vertebra, sacralization of the lumbar vertebra (L5), and multiple perineural cysts 
Eye: bilateral cataracts, large optic discs, and thinned retinas

evidence.dc:description: SD GCEP Scoring Guidance Specifications for consanguinity/homozygosity

evidence.rdfs:label: 18.12DG1149
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
3y5mo boy born to a G1 P0 mother, pregnancy complicated by polyhydramnios. Term delivery via NSVD with a BW of 3.2 kg. Parents het.
Fam hx: Parents are 1st degree consanguineous, with a fam hx of 2 distant cousins with similar features (not tested). Excessive neonatal crying during defecation due to a small anal orifice
Developmental: Dev delay in fine motor & cognitive skills. IQ<70
Dental: Hx of delayed dental eruption.
Craniofacial dysmorphism: Borderline microcephaly (at -2 SD). Synophrys, discontinuation of eyebrows at the middle, broad nasal bridge, hypertelorism, proptosis, upturned nostril, malar hypoplasia, thin upper lip, absent upper incisors, prominent infra-lips crease, mildly pointed chin
Genital/other dysmorphism: widely spaced nipple with central dimple, anteriorly displaced anus, bifid scrotum, cryptorchidism, severe hypospadias.
Skeletal: short fingers.  Echocardiogram, abdominal US, brain MRI were all otherwise unremarkable.

evidence.dc:description: Deducting half a point each for homozygosity and consanguinity per SD GCEP Scoring Guidance Specifications
